awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: MODULUS: Modeling and Experimental Investigation of Protein Crowding on Lipid Bilayers
awd_abstract_narration:
Cellular membranes separate the contents of the cell from the environment. In addition to demarcating cellular boundaries, these membranes perform critical functions such as the uptake of nutrients and drugs into the cell and ejection of material out of the cell. Membranes perform these functions by interacting with many different proteins. Therefore, understanding how membrane-protein interactions take place is critical for gaining insight not just into how cells function but also for understanding how viruses can hijack cells or how better drug delivery systems can be designed. The work proposed here will result in new computational algorithms and experimental tools to understand how cellular membranes interact with proteins to regulate these fundamental functions. The insights generated from our effort will fill major gaps in current understanding about how the cell membrane can change its shape to affect its function. These insights have the potential to benefit society in multiple ways including (i) improving understanding of the mechanisms that pathogens use to invade cells, suggesting new therapeutic strategies; (ii) inspiring the design of better systems for drug and gene delivery, and; (iii) revealing fundamental mechanisms that structure and organize soft matter, potentially leading to improvements in technologies that rely on such materials including surfactants, cosmetics, fuels, and foods. 

Membrane curvature plays a role in nearly every cellular function, in both health and disease. The curvature of the membrane is mediated by many proteins that interact with lipids. In this proposal, we will develop new theoretical and computational models of membrane-protein interactions with a focus on understanding how protein crowding can lead to membrane curvature generation. This effort combines multiscale modeling of membrane bending with quantitative detailed experimental measurements of membrane surface coverage, steric pressure, and curvature. The multiscale modeling efforts include coarse-grained models of lipid bilayer-protein interactions that will inform the continuum models of membrane curvature generation. The team of investigators includes an experimental biophysicist, a theoretical biophysicist, and mathematicians. The insights generated from our efforts will fill major gaps in current understanding of how membrane curvature is generated and stabilized. We also anticipate these applications driving additional development of the theory and numerical treatment of nonlinear geometric partial differential equations posed on surfaces with constraints.  Additionally, the team of investigators will participate in outreach and educational activities, including programs for high school students, undergraduate research opportunities, and new course development. This award was co-funded by Systems and Synthetic Biology in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Mathematical Biology Program of the Division of Mathematical Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our work under this award investigated the impact of the biophysical interactions between proteins on biological substrates including lipid membrane bilayers and cytoskeletal filaments. In particular, we investigated proteins that undergo liquid-liquid phase separation to form liquid-like condensates surrounded by a dilute, protein-depleted phase. When this phase separation occurs on the surfaces of lipid bilayer membranes, we found that, rather than remaining flat, the membrane bend away from the condensate creating a protein-lined membrane invagination or tubule. Through a combination of computational modeling and experiment, we determined that protein condensates apply a compressive stress to membrane surfaces, giving rise to the observed changes in membrane curvature. These findings appear to be broadly applicable, as they can be observed with condensates and membranes having a broad range of molecular compositions. As such, these findings could be used to help explain diverse cellular structures in which protein assembly at membrane surfaces such as filopodia, viral buds, and tubular organelles. 

In a second major thrust of the project, we developed a novel approach for sensing the crowded environment on the surfaces of biological membranes. Our approach used a fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) to sense the impact of steric pressure on flexible polymers adhered to the surfaces of membranes. In particular, our sensor consisted of a flexible biological or synthetic polymer adhered at one end to a membrane surface. The free end of the polymer was conjugated to a FRET donor fluorophore, while the membrane surface was densely labeled with acceptor fluorophores. As the membrane surface became more crowded, the flexible polymer was forced to straighten, resulting in displacement of the donor fluorophore further and further from the acceptor-labeled membrane. This displacement resulting in a lengthening of the donor fluorescent lifetime. By comparing these changes in donor lifetime to a simple tethered polymer model, we were able to extract estimates of the steric pressure on the membrane surface resulting from crowding. Using this sensor we showed that (i) steric pressure on membrane surfaces is capable of driving membrane fission, and (ii) intrinsically disordered proteins are potent crowders of the membrane surface owing to their large hydrodynamic radii. This work helps to explain the biophysical environment on the surfaces of biological membranes, which are ubiquitously crowded. These findings are relevant to a broad range of phenomena, from receptor-ligand binding and viral infection of host cells to the bending of membranes during the biogenesis of cellular organelles. 

In the third major thrust of this project, we demonstrated that protein condensates can apply biophysical forces to cytoskeletal filaments, resulting in changes to filament architecture. In particular, we discovered that when actin interacting proteins form liquid-like condensates, these condensates locally concentrate actin, resulting in actin polymerization. As filaments grow inside condensates, they encounter the surface tension of the droplet, which confines them within the droplet. As filament length begins to exceed droplet diameter, the filaments move spontaneously to the inner surface of the droplets in order to minimize their curvature. As the filaments concentrate at the droplet surface, they begin to form bundles, which eventually overcome the droplet surface tension. As the droplet surface tension gives way to filament rigidity, the droplet deforms, allowing the filaments to straighten into linear, parallel bundles. This previously unknown phenomenon could be explained by a simple physical model, which balanced the filament curvature energy against the droplet surface energy. These findings could help to explain how bundled filament architectures such as filopodia and stress fibers assemble in cells. 

Taken together, work under this project has combined experimental data with computational modeling to extend fundamental understanding of the interactions between flexible protein networks and biophysical substrates such as membranes and cytoskeletal filaments. This work has a broad range of potential applications from explaining cellular physiology to illustrating principles that could be used to design active soft matter systems such as foods, fuels, and therapeutics.
